dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, I was reading this wild piece the other day, and it had some pretty surprising stats about US productivity. Like, really surprising.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, I was reading this wild piece the other day, and it had some pretty surprising stats about U S productivity. Like, really surprising.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah? What'd you find, A? Because, you know, usually we think of the US as, like, the powerhouse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah? What'd you find, A? Because, you know, usually we think of the U S as, like, the powerhouse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! But apparently, over the last two decades, since 2004, US productivity growth has just completely *lagged* behind the Eurozone. Like, massively.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But apparently, over the last two decades, since two thousand four, U S productivity growth has just completely lagged behind the Eurozone. Like, massively.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two decades since 2004, US productivity growth, as measured by the value of output per hour worked, has been more than double that of the eurozone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, really? Because I thought Europe was, uh, you know, a bit slower on that front.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? Because I thought Europe was, uh, you know, a bit slower on that front.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Nope! The article says Eurozone productivity has soared, even seen a marked increase since COVID. But US non-farm output per hour? It's *fallen* by more than 6% in the same period.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope! The article says Eurozone productivity has soared, even seen a marked increase since C O V I D. But U S non-farm output per hour? It's fallen by more than six percent in the same period.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whereas eurozone productivity has flat-lined and even fallen slightly since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. Six percent down? That's... that's kind of disastrous by our own historical standards, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. Six percent down? That's... that's kind of disastrous by our own historical standards, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period more than adequate performance by Americas own historical standards.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It really makes you wonder what's going on. Some people point to, like, the US's fiscal stimulus post-pandemic, saying it was lackluster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It really makes you wonder what's going on. Some people point to, like, the U S's fiscal stimulus post-pandemic, saying it was lackluster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some accounts point to the strong fiscal stimulus applied in the US since the outbreak of the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, but I thought strong stimulus could actually decrease output and employment growth? So that wouldn't necessarily explain *slower* productivity. It's a bit of a mixed bag, no?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, but I thought strong stimulus could actually decrease output and employment growth? So that wouldn't necessarily explain slower productivity. It's a bit of a mixed bag, no?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But while strong spending stimulus can trigger rapid output and employment growth, it is not clear why it should produce faster productivity growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the article kinda debunks that easy explanation. It suggests something else might be at play, like our tight labor markets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the article kinda debunks that easy explanation. It suggests something else might be at play, like our tight labor markets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's interesting. You mean, uh, businesses over-hiring, maybe bringing on too many unskilled workers because it's hard to find labor?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's interesting. You mean, uh, businesses over-hiring, maybe bringing on too many unskilled workers because it's hard to find labor?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...given strong employment growth and tight labor markets, one might expect US companies to be forced to take on less productive workers, with negative implications for output per hour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It gives this example: you go to a US bank, you see tons of human tellers, very few ATMs. Or, like, even at fancy restaurants, you're always using a waiter service.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It gives this example: you go to a U S bank, you see tons of human tellers, very few A T Miss Or, like, even at fancy restaurants, you're always using a waiter service.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans visiting a bank branch will encounter plenty of ATMs but sometimes not a single human teller. They are compelled to order meals, even at white-tablecloth restaurants, using a QR code.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Oh, I've noticed that! I mean, I love good service, but it does make you think about, like, efficiency. And you'd expect, you know, more tech adoption.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I've noticed that! I mean, I love good service, but it does make you think about, like, efficiency. And you'd expect, you know, more tech adoption.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? But then the article says US underperformance in tech sectors was actually *before* the 2008 crisis, not recently. And AI? Apparently, it's being used to *lower* productivity right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But then the article says U S underperformance in tech sectors was actually before the two thousand eight crisis, not recently. And A I? Apparently, it's being used to lower productivity right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US outperformance in computer producing and using sectors was most pronounced in the decade preceding the global financial crisis, not in the period since.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, AI is *lowering* productivity? That seems counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, A I is lowering productivity? That seems counterintuitive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's that 'productivity J-curve' thing. Where you reorganize for new tech, things get worse before they get better. So, maybe we're just in the trough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's that productivity J-curve thing. Where you reorganize for new tech, things get worse before they get better. So, maybe we're just in the trough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The inevitability of errors means that productivity is likely to fall before rising, a phenomenon economists call the productivity J-curve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what about Europe then? Are they just, like, incredibly smart with their tech, or did they get lucky?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what about Europe then? Are they just, like, incredibly smart with their tech, or did they get lucky?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it could be a bit of luck. The article mentions things like EU data privacy rules, which, ironically, if ignored, might speed up AI development. And, uh, maybe Putin's energy-price boon helped Europe avoid disruptions the US faced.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it could be a bit of luck. The article mentions things like E U data privacy rules, which, ironically, if ignored, might speed up A I development. And, uh, maybe Putin's energy-price boon helped Europe avoid disruptions the U S faced.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Finally, it could simply be that Europe has had bad luck, specifically in the form of Russian President Vladimir Putin and his energy-price shock. The US, being self-sufficient in energy, has not been vulnerable to energy-supply disruptions to the same degree.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So, less reliance on energy imports meant European firms didn't have to suspend operations as much. That would definitely help productivity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So, less reliance on energy imports meant European firms didn't have to suspend operations as much. That would definitely help productivity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: European firms, in contrast, have been forced to suspend their most energy-intensive operations or else to engage in costly restructuring, which is not good for productivity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah. And then there's this really sarcastic bit about Mario Draghi and his supposed recommendations for Europe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah. And then there's this really sarcastic bit about Mario Draghi and his supposed recommendations for Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the 'avoiding investments in new technologies' and 'maintaining barriers to competition' part? [chuckles]
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the avoiding investments in new technologies and maintaining barriers to competition part?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No doubt, he will recommend completing Europes capital-markets union so that firms can more easily finance investments in new technologies. Draghi will recommend removing barriers to competition, which would intensify the pressure on firms to innovate in order to survive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Exactly! And advocating for energy inefficiency! It's so obviously the *opposite* of what you'd actually want. The article's basically saying, 'these are the dumbest ideas ever, Europe needs old ones.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And advocating for energy inefficiency! It's so obviously the opposite of what you'd actually want. The article's basically saying, these are the dumbest ideas ever, Europe needs old ones.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He will advocate greater energy efficiency and self-sufficiency to free Europe from more Putin-like disruptions. ... Europe should move now to implement these old ideas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Man, that's, uh, quite a take. So, basically, the US is surprisingly struggling, Europe's doing surprisingly well, and the solutions are way more complicated than anyone thinks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Man, that's, uh, quite a take. So, basically, the U S is surprisingly struggling, Europe's doing surprisingly well, and the solutions are way more complicated than anyone thinks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Something seems to be going seriously right in the US and seriously wrong in Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much sums it up! It's a real head-scratcher.
